author: Grimms
text: There was once a cook named Gretel, who wore shoes with red heels, and when she walked out with them on, she turned herself this way and that, was quite happy and thought: "You certainly are a pretty girl!"

author: Grimms
text: And when she came home she drank, in her gladness of heart, a draught of wine, and as wine excites a desire to eat, she tasted the best of whatever she was cooking until she was satisfied, and said: "The cook must know what the food is like."

author: Grimms
text: It came to pass that the master one day said to her: "Gretel, there is a guest coming this evening; prepare me two fowls very daintily."

author: Grimms
text: "I will see to it, master," answered Gretel.

author: Grimms
text: She killed two fowls, scalded them, plucked them, put them on the spit, and towards evening set them before the fire, that they might roast.

author: Grimms
text: The fowls began to turn brown, and were nearly ready, but the guest had not yet arrived.

author: Grimms
text: Then Gretel called out to her master: "If the guest does not come, I must take the fowls away from the fire, but it will be a sin and a shame if they are not eaten the moment they are at their juiciest."

author: Grimms
text: The master said: "I will run myself, and fetch the guest."

author: Grimms
text: When the master had turned his back, Gretel laid the spit with the fowls on one side, and thought: "Standing so long by the fire there, makes one sweat and thirsty; who knows when they will come?

author: Grimms
text: Meanwhile, I will run into the cellar, and take a drink."

author: Grimms
text: She ran down, set a jug, said: "God bless it for you, Gretel," and took a good drink, and thought that wine should flow on, and should not be interrupted, and took yet another hearty draught.

author: Grimms
text: Then she went and put the fowls down again to the fire, basted them, and drove the spit merrily round.

author: Grimms
text: But as the roast meat smelt so good, Gretel thought: "Something might be wrong, it ought to be tasted!"

author: Grimms
text: She touched it with her finger, and said: "Ah! how good fowls are!

author: Grimms
text: It certainly is a sin and a shame that they are not eaten at the right time!"

author: Grimms
text: She ran to the window, to see if the master was not coming with his guest, but she saw no one, and went back to the fowls and thought: "One of the wings is burning!

author: Grimms
text: I had better take it off and eat it."

author: Grimms
text: So she cut it off, ate it, and enjoyed it, and when she had done, she thought: "The other must go down too, or else master will observe that something is missing."

author: Grimms
text: When the two wings were eaten, she went and looked for her master, and did not see him.

author: Grimms
text: It suddenly occurred to her: "Who knows?

author: Grimms
text: They are perhaps not coming at all, and have turned in somewhere."

author: Grimms
text: Then she said: "Well, Gretel, enjoy yourself, one fowl has been cut into, take another drink, and eat it up entirely; when it is eaten you will have some peace, why should God"s good gifts be spoilt?"

author: Grimms
text: So she ran into the cellar again, took an enormous drink and ate up the one chicken in great glee.

author: Grimms
text: When one of the chickens was swallowed down, and still her master did not come, Gretel looked at the other and said: "What one is, the other should be likewise, the two go together; what"s right for the one is right for the other; I think if I were to take another draught it would do me no harm."

author: Grimms
text: So she took another hearty drink, and let the second chicken follow the first.

author: Grimms
text: While she was making the most of it, her master came and cried: "Hurry up, Gretel, the guest is coming directly after me!"

author: Grimms
text: "Yes, sir, I will soon serve up," answered Gretel.

author: Grimms
text: Meantime the master looked to see what the table was properly laid, and took the great knife, wherewith he was going to carve the chickens, and sharpened it on the steps.

author: Grimms
text: Presently the guest came, and knocked politely and courteously at the house-door.

author: Grimms
text: Gretel ran, and looked to see who was there, and when she saw the guest, she put her finger to her lips and said: "Hush! hush! go away as quickly as you can, if my master catches you it will be the worse for you; he certainly did ask you to supper, but his intention is to cut off your two ears.

author: Grimms
text: Just listen how he is sharpening the knife for it!"

author: Grimms
text: The guest heard the sharpening, and hurried down the steps again as fast as he could.

author: Grimms
text: Gretel was not idle; she ran screaming to her master, and cried: "You have invited a fine guest!"

author: Grimms
text: "Why, Gretel?

author: Grimms
text: What do you mean by that?"

author: Grimms
text: "Yes," said she, "he has taken the chickens which I was just going to serve up, off the dish, and has run away with them!"

author: Grimms
text: "That"s a nice trick!" said her master, and lamented the fine chickens.

author: Grimms
text: "If he had but left me one, so that something remained for me to eat."

author: Grimms
text: He called to him to stop, but the guest pretended not to hear.

author: Grimms
text: Then he ran after him with the knife still in his hand, crying: "Just one, just one," meaning that the guest should leave him just one chicken, and not take both.

author: Grimms
text: The guest, however, thought no otherwise than that he was to give up one of his ears, and ran as if fire were burning under him, in order to take them both with him.
